newsitem.title: USA: US adj retail sales up 1.7 pct w/e June 28-Redbook.
newsitem.headline: US adj retail sales up 1.7 pct w/e June 28-Redbook.

text.p: U.S. seasonally adjusted retail sales rose 1.7 percent in the four weeks of fiscal June versus last month, according to the Lynch, Jones & Ryan Inc Redbook Retail Sales Index.

The index rose 8.2 percent compared with the same month a year ago, the report said. Adjusted retail sales advanced 8.6 percent in the week ended June 28, compared with the same week a year ago, it said.
Most retailers reported sales were on-to-above plan in the fourth week of June, said Howard Eilenberg, a retail analyst at Redbook Research.
Eilenberg said retailers cited the summer heat for the weekly increase in sales of seasonal goods, such as air conditioners, fans, pool and beach equipment, and warm weather apparel.
"This should help to clear (inventory) out," said Eilenberg in an interview with Reuters Financial Television.
"When the quarter is over, the margins will be protected and merchandise would've moved out," he said.
Earlier worries about increased inventories and markdowns have lessened, noted Eilenberg.
"July is a clearance month ... but there won't be panic markdowns. The hot weather arrived just in time," he said.
Regionally, retail sales were relatively robust in the Northeast and West Coast.
Looking ahead, Eilenberg said retailers should continue to see strong year-on-year comparisons next month.
"July 1996 was not a good month and so the comparisons will be relatively easy," he added.
There were five weeks in June and month-end figures are expected to be released next Thursday.
